prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We are asking for two epochs to fit physical parameters during two different gamma-ray. Sources could be observed as suits the schedule as the have been chosen specifically to be gamma-ray active at all times. Thus these epochs do not have to be at any particular time of year or conform to any special cadence as long as there is a gap of a few weeks between them. We do request notification of when ALMA observes a source so that multiwavelength quasi-simultaneous observations can be arranged.

We are asking for two epochs to fit physical parameters during two different gamma-ray. Sources could be observed as suits the schedule as the have been chosen specifically to be gamma-ray active at all times. Thus these epochs do not have to be at any particular time of year or conform to any special cadence as long as there is a gap of a few weeks between them. We do request notification of when ALMA observes a source so that multiwavelength quasi-simultaneous observations can be arranged.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our ATCA observations indicate that our sources will be unresolved in all ALMA configurations so any configuration is acceptable. We are not imaging these sources, only taking flux density measurements. Thus uv coverage is not an issue.
Estimates of peak flux density (entered into the ALMA observing tool) were taken from the Planck catalog. Sources that were not in the Planck catalog had their flux estimated from WMAP data or from lower frequency observations.
The sensitivities chosen for this experiment will provide lower uncertainties in the measurement of flux density than those obtained with the Planck satellite. The requested sensitivity of observations are set so that we will be able to achieve a sensitivity better than 0.05 Jy for all four bands. This sensitivity is sufficient to detect all our sources and allow for monitoring of flux variation.
We request dual polarisation to increase sensitivity. Bands were chosen to well sample the low energy synchrotron component of the emission.
Based on time estimates from the OT tool achieving the desired sensitivity will require ~1 hour per source per band. We are uncertain if full calibration is required for each source.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We are asking for two epochs to fit physical parameters during two different gamma-ray. Sources could be observed as suits the schedule as the have been chosen specifically to be gamma-ray active at all times. Thus these epochs do not have to be at any particular time of year or conform to any special cadence as long as there is a gap of a few weeks between them. We do request notification of when ALMA observes a source so that multiwavelength quasi-simultaneous observations can be arranged.

We are asking for two epochs to fit physical parameters during two different gamma-ray. Sources could be observed as suits the schedule as the have been chosen specifically to be gamma-ray active at all times. Thus these epochs do not have to be at any particular time of year or conform to any special cadence as long as there is a gap of a few weeks between them. We do request notification of when ALMA observes a source so that multiwavelength quasi-simultaneous observations can be arranged.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our ATCA observations indicate that our sources will be unresolved in all ALMA configurations so any configuration is acceptable. We are not imaging these sources, only taking flux density measurements. Thus uv coverage is not an issue.
Estimates of peak flux density (entered into the ALMA observing tool) were taken from the Planck catalog. Sources that were not in the Planck catalog had their flux estimated from WMAP data or from lower frequency observations.
The sensitivities chosen for this experiment will provide lower uncertainties in the measurement of flux density than those obtained with the Planck satellite. The requested sensitivity of observations are set so that we will be able to achieve a sensitivity better than 0.05 Jy for all four bands. This sensitivity is sufficient to detect all our sources and allow for monitoring of flux variation.
We request dual polarisation to increase sensitivity. Bands were chosen to well sample the low energy synchrotron component of the emission.
Based on time estimates from the OT tool achieving the desired sensitivity will require ~1 hour per source per band. We are uncertain if full calibration is required for each source.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Broadband SEDs are a powerful tool to distinguish between different models attempting to explain high energy emission from blazars. Submillimeter observations with ALMA will provide critical constraints to blazar SEDs. In combination with space and ground based facilities from radio to TeV bands, ALMA observations will provide quasi-simultaneous broadband coverage at an unprecedented level. The TANAMI program proposes to construct the broadband SEDs of a group of the gamma-ray brightest blazars in the southern hemisphere. Modelfitting of these SEDs will be combined with parameters obtained from VLBI monitoring to address basic questions about the physics of blazars.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.01075.S, Observations of Gamma Ray Bright Southern Hemisphere Blazars, Michael Dutka
